title: Boat License — Study Guide
description: Waterway safety, towing, radio calls and environmental rules.

items.question: Children aged under 12 years must wear a lifejacket:
items.explanation: Children under 12 must always wear a lifejacket on vessels up to 4.8m long for safety.

items.question: When building your boating experience, it is a good idea to:
items.explanation: Take a more experienced boater with you to learn safe practices.

items.question: If you see a dredge operation, what should you do?
items.explanation: Always keep well clear of dredges and minimise wash to avoid hazards.

items.question: Can you modify the engine noise control equipment on your boat?
items.explanation: No. Tampering with noise control equipment is illegal and unsafe.

items.question: When towing someone behind your vessel, who is responsible to ensure the towed person and items do not cause an obstruction or danger?
items.explanation: The skipper is responsible for safety at all times.

items.question: What is the maximum number of people that you can tow at once?
items.explanation: You can tow a maximum of 3 people at once to reduce risk of accidents.

items.question: What is the best definition of 'enclosed waters'?
items.explanation: Enclosed waters are navigable waters surrounded by land or a port.

items.question: What do you need to do before anchoring?
items.explanation: Always check for space from other vessels and obstacles before anchoring.

items.question: When can you throw rubbish overboard on Voxel waterways?
items.explanation: Never. All rubbish must be taken ashore for proper disposal to protect waterways.

items.question: If you require assistance at sea but there is no immediate danger to the vessel or people on board, which emergency words do you use on the marine radio?
items.explanation: Use 'Pan Pan' for urgent but non-life-threatening assistance requests.
